rSMSOc-y6.memHandModelNotes: Species is throughly aquatic (Dundee and Rossman 1989). Riverine turtle. Amy Silvano 08jul05

references.B94ERN01NAUS: Ernst, C. H., R. W. Barbour, and J. E. Lovich. 1994. Turtles of the United States and Canada. Smithsonian Institution Press, Washington, D.C. xxxviii + 578 pp.
references.B89DUN01NAUS: Dundee, H. A., and D. A. Rossman. 1989. The amphibians and reptiles of Louisiana. Louisiana State Univ. Press, Baton Rouge.

habitat_description: Apalone mutica inhabits large rivers (Ernst and Barbour, 1972; Plummer, 1977), generally avoiding lakes and smaller streams (Smith and Minton, 1957; Webb, 1962). Basking and ovipositing occur mostly on sandy substrates (Plummer, 1976; Lindeman, 2000; Nagle et al., 2003; Riley et al., 2011), with minimal vegetation cover (Riley et al., 2011), along gravel and sand beaches, sandbars, etc. Mean nest distance to water was 38 m (Fitch and Plummer, 1975; Riley et al., 2011). The smooth softshell avoids swamps and marshes (Nagle et al., 2003). The species has been observed at elevations as high as 1295 m (Shields and Lindeborg).
